links.title: The Biggest Flaw In Tesla's Cars
links.description: In my last Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) article, I advanced what proved to be a very controversial idea: that the problem with Tesla was not getting its batteries big enough, but rather that they were far too big already. The idea received quite a lot of pushback, to say the least.

messages.body: 80-Year-Old UAW Takes on 14-Year-Old Tesla $TSLA http://bit.ly/2lC4eOu $TSLA #tesla #uaw

links.title: 80-Year-Old UAW Takes on 14-Year-Old Tesla
links.description: When Tesla Inc. (NASDAQ: TSLA) started in 2003, CEO Elon Musk could never have imagined his electric car company would face the prospects of workers who would want to be part of a union. Recently, he found out that the 82-year-old United Automobile Workers (UAW) plans to treat Tesla much as it does other car companies.

links.title: Tesla chief in public feud with auto workers union
links.description: A feud between Elon Musk and the United Automobile Workers revved up on Friday as the group denied his accusation they planted a mole to unionize Tesla employees. The UAW statement was the latest twist in a saga triggered by an online post by a man who claimed to work at Tesla's plant in California for four years and decried conditions faced by employees there.

message.body: $TSLA $5-$14 upside share price increase (TSLA) will come from another business Morgan Stanely says http://www.investopedia.com/news/battery-storage-boost-tesla-stock-morgan-stanley-tsla/

links.title: Battery Storage to Boost Tesla Stock: Morgan Stanley
links.description: While its electric cars dominate headlines and bring in revenue, Tesla, Inc.'s ( TSLA) stock could receive a further boost from another business in its product portfolio, according to analysts at Morgan Stanley. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based company's shares could see "potential upside" of between $5 and $14 per share, depending on the market share of its battery storage business.
